MainClaim.text: "Dichotomies are artifacts that we devise with some useful purpose in mind

Untitled1.text: "Putnam's approach to distinctions and dichotomies is aligned with the rejection of modern philosophy's dualism."

Untitled2.text: "Dichotomies are artifacts that we devise with some useful purpose in mind."

Untitled3.text: "Dichotomies appear when and where there are human beings thinking

Untitled4.text: "Dichotomies are mainly a form of logical division

Untitled5.text: "The transformation of a distinction into a metaphysical dichotomy turns the distinction into a Procrustean bed."

Untitled6.text: "Putnam has demonstrated convincingly that the fact/value dichotomy is

Untitled7.text: "The fact/value dichotomy is a way of cutting off not only rational argument about values

Untitled9.text: "Putnam identifies three reasons why we are tempted to establish the fact/value dichotomy."

Untitled10.text: "The first reason is that the fact/value dichotomy is a way of cutting off not only rational argument about values

Untitled11.text: "The second reason is that this dichotomy is a way of cutting off rational argument about values."

Untitled12.text: "The third reason is that the fact/value dichotomy is a way of cutting off thought."

Untitled13.text: "Putnam holds that thick ethical concepts are counterexamples to the claim that there is an absolute fact/value dichotomy."

Untitled14.text: "Thick ethical concepts are counterexamples to the claim that there is an absolute fact/value dichotomy."

Untitled15.text: "The application of intelligence to moral problems is itself a moral obligation."

Untitled17.text: "The border between fact and value is faint: the terms considered to have a function of ethical evaluation have also a descriptive explicative and predictive function."

Untitled18.text: "The concept of a lamp is a mixture of description and evaluation."

Untitled19.text: "The use of the term 'lamp' involves some evaluation about the extension of the concept."

Untitled22.text: "The making of dichotomies was perhaps seen by the vast majority of our colleagues in the past century as a useful tool to make philosophical progress."

Untitled23.text: "The dichotomy between value judgments and judgments of facts was not really a dichotomy

Untitled24.text: "The fact/value dichotomy blocks inquiry and distorts our view of rationality and human flourishing."

Untitled25.text: "The view of language that Austin presents in the last lecture of How to Do Things with Words fits pretty well with a pragmatist approach to language."

Untitled26.text: "Austin characterizes the dichotomy between the normative or evaluative and the factual as a'fetish'."

Untitled27.text: "The dichotomy between the normative or evaluative and the factual is a'fetish'."

Untitled28.text: "Austin's view of language is aligned with the pragmatist tradition."

Untitled29.text: "The dichotomy between the normative or evaluative and the factual is an artifact

Untitled30.text: "The dichotomy between the normative or evaluative and the factual is a thesis
